p: All CMGs focused on bacterial CNS infections recommended adjunctive corticosteroids therapy before or with first dose of antibiotics. Some recommended it up to a few hours [ 37], 4 h [ 5, 39], 12 h [ 2, 24] or 24 h post-antibiotics [ 20, 35]. Four explicitly did not recommend steroids for patients with immunosuppression [ 34] or for neonates [ 5, 24, 44]. One CMG noted that corticosteroids in infants is controversial and only recommended for Hib meningitis [ 44]. It was highlighted that corticosteroids can reduce inflammation and brain oedema and has in some studies shown benefits of reducing rates of complications and improving outcomes in patients with meningitis, but also that some studies have raised concerns about potential side effects [ 2].
